sub_title: Experienced Software Architect, (.NET) Software Engineer and (SPA) Web Developer.
summary:
Having successfully played many roles in IT, at heart I'm still an engineer.

I'm quite flexible in the position or role I can do, be it Software Architect, .Net Software Engineer or React Web Developer. In all those roles, I try to analyse and improve software systems, business processes and the process of creating software. As I'm an experienced modern software architect and have extensive architecture knowledge, that I use to help agile teams build better software. I like to communicate an inspiring vision of the future and supporting people along the way.

Every system has an architecture, but a good design with e.g. Domain Driven Development (DDD) with Microservices can avoid a lot of pitfalls. Modelling the business logic with UML gives insight to engineers, simplifying development and avoid accidents for new hires. While it can also enable performance and mitigate the fallout of accidents.

My experience with processes such as Kanban and Scrum, architectures such as Microservices, SOA and the layer model, methods such as TDD and BDD, principles such as SOLID, IoC, KISS, DRY, YAGNI and SoC (Separation of Concerns) and patterns such as the Design Patterns and GRASP (General Responsibility Assignment Software Patterns) mean that I can participate in any development team and that in many cases I can take the team to a higher level.

For 2 decades I have specialize in .NET development. The ever improving framework makes a solid foundation for any application. The reach it has makes it easy to integrate many aspects of development. It was open from the start, so I have been able to use open source solutions where they fit. Therefor I have branched out to things like ReactJS, Kafka, RabbidMQ, Redis, PostgreSQL, Docker and Kubernetes to name a few.

After decades of keeping tabs on what is current in IT and having a passion for learning combined with a wide range of interests, I have gained extensive knowledge in many field, like coding, psychology, design and management. This means that I can settle in quickly and can also offer added value in less clearly defined roles.

treasury_media.title: Marcel Sorger's Shelfari books
treasury_media.description: I'm always updating my skill's, so check out the books I'm reading.

profile_positions.description:
I transitioned smoothly from the Motorschoppen project to GSL MES, that intends to rebuild the ancient EVA system with .Net and Angular. EVA is a huge system that needs to be rebuild before the current maintainers start to enjoy their pension in 2025.
Although I'm a partner at TFG and a freelancer, many at Tata considered me part of the furniture. Current agreement is to stay on until the end of 2025, which is a bit long for a freelance assignment. However the challenge is great and the need is high. 
This is also the place where I can do most good, as the energy transition will not be completed by people demonstrating in stupid places or households using multiple bins to put their waste in.
profile_positions.title: Consultant

profile_positions.description:
I'm back at Tata after 10 years for my 4th stint. This time I'm developing a IOT application to track the shovels in the harbor picking up ore and dumping it in funnels. It's an innovative project to prohibit mistakes and optimize workflow. 
Technically the shovel is tracked with GPS. It's position and state are communicated over 4G to Azure IOT and Azure Functions, then further to on premise servers. Assignments are created in an Aurelia Single Page Application (SPA) and flow the other way. They are made visible on an embedded tablet on the shovel with UWP/WinUI3. The REST services, forming the core of the system, are state of the art .Net with things like MediatR and FluentValidations. The Scrum process is supported by Azure DevOps with full CI/CD.
Lots of research hurdles to take and we had some force majeure technical setbacks. Luckily, we have a great team and other departments are supporting us, so we're making progress, nevertheless. 
It looks like this project is a showcase for the technical prowess of Tata Steel. It coincides with the other ingenious project of using hydrogen to make steel. In my mind this is an essential project for the future of the company as a mayor benefactor to the region, the future of European industry as an integrated system and the future of the world as an ecology. My contribution to that greater goal, however little, is something I value and I'm glad I can do my part.
profile_positions.title: Consultant

profile_positions.description: The Future Group is a great partner to have as a freelancer. It's a trading partnership in the IT field, that has great sales and marketing, a big network and a big reputation in the field. Together with a solid administration and the social aspects of other like minded technology experts, makes for a very attractive organization to partner with. It's also a bonus that there are a lot of friendly and helpful people there.
profile_positions.title: Partner

profile_positions.description:
The lotteries run a high traffic website with 8 million users a month. In the front-end of the websites there is a need for a rebuild, after they have been adapted and maintained for 15 years. Als the move to the, in NL less known, Norwegian CMS Enonic has had an impact. The CMS has excellent scalability and streamlines web publishing. It runs on top of ElasticSearch and Hazelcast, is written in Java and has the capability to compile JavaScript to Java with PurlpleJS. This makes it very fast, although somewhat quirky to work with.
I have worked as part of the Scrum team, mainly focusing on research for the next version of the front-end websites. GraphQL, ReactJS/Next.js, WebPack, Typescript and TailwindCSS have been incorporated into the architecture, as well as unit testing with Jest and code guidelines adherence with Pretty among other things. I have created a Proof of Concept, a Component library and lots of documentation. The team should have a flying start, when they start with the rebuild.
Personally, after decades of Microsoft C# .Net, the Java world has been an interesting change of scenery. I've always been independent of MS and very much involved with the general crafting of software, so there are many synergies, although lots of details work differently than expected. As a bonus, the team and company culture are a great match. As they say "Winnen do je bij de Postcode Loterij".
profile_positions.title: Web Developer

profile_positions.description:
I started my sabbatical because my start-up had left me drained, to fix private things and to better my health as to avoid Covid. Unfortunately I did contract Covid in march and it was nasty. Luckily no hospital was needed, although it was close. The aftermath took longer then I expected, as I couldn't smell anything for a month and even worse, I was dead tired for multiple months. After recuperating it was my mother who went ill. I don't feel free to tell the details, but suffice to say that cancer is a serious illness made worse during a pandemic. 
The initial hysteria of Covid made going back to a job less attractive. Also I value real world team interaction and a physical Kanban board, over remote work. Now I feel that the hysteria has passed and remote work has improved technically and more importantly socially.

During my sabbatical I created Fountain Exponential and Open Game Asset Structure. These are both projects that aim to improve fundamental aspects of game development. The technologies from these projects are intended to be integrated into multiple game engines, to make dialog and other assets reusable between game engines.
To publish my findings I'm working on a number of articles. They will be in essay format to make it easy to adopt and explain. Back in 2000 I basically created the Entity Component System (ECS), but only published it as my Engineering degree paper and not in the trades. I left game development disillusioned because of the lack of professionalism. In 2006 ECS was presented by somebody else at a game trade show. It remained a promising architecture without making any inroads, but now ECS is going mainstream with Unity ECS. In 2000 I did the community a disservice not to stand by what I created and aim to do better now.
The first of the essay's is attached below.
profile_positions.title: Creator

profile_positions.description:
SkyReckon is the continuation our CodeStratosphere start-up. My role as co-founder and IT-Manager was, because of the size of the team, more hands on then managerial, although I did a lot of business development, coaching and instructing. The technical side of the business was my responsibility, as my co-founder handled the marketing and administration. We tried to create a cutting edge solution for the leasing industry, where we used all the leading technologies and tried to better understand our customers, in order to deliver a superior product. Unfortunately this created a perfect storm, of a paradigm shift to functional programming in the front-end, distributed computing in the back-end, containers for infrastructure and the complex domain logic of the aircraft industry plus high finance. Technical, the thing that did me in, was the issue of putting inherently relational data in a document database. Switching from Redis to PostgreSQL was going to solve it, but it also surfaced the differences between the founders. Perceiving the context as being in different Cynefin domains, lead to different behaviors or Hanlon's razor combined with the Dunning–Kruger effect applies. Either way, with the outlook on the market changed, I lost confidence in the company being a good investment.

For the analysis of the domain I used Domain Driven Design (DDD), designing a micro-service architecture with CQRS and event-sourcing, describing the architecture in ao UML, taking special care for the aspects of ergonomy, consistency and security. The used technologies, Asp.net core, React-Redux, Webpack, Lodash, Bootstrap, Kafka, Redis, PostgreSQL, Logstash(ELK), Docker, Kubernetes needed extensive research. The implementation was mainly done in Typescript for the single page application (SPA), C# for the back-end RESTfull WebApi plus consumers and Powershell for the infrastructure. We used Azure DevOps Services (TFS) for our Scrum development process and DevOps integration.
profile_positions.title: IT Manager

profile_positions.description:
Uniserver is a cloud infrastructure supplier that tries to make things as simple as possible for their clients. The initial project I designed and worked on introduced a payment scheme similar to those in the telephone industry where you buy a bundle of resources like vCpu and memory hours and deploy it however you like. Competitors, Azure, Amazon and others, are notorious for their woolly pricing needing a combination of a mathematician and a fortune-teller to forecast your bill with them. The design I made and helped implement involved administrating and pricing the resources in such a way that the calculations could be traced back to there origin, similar to accounting.

After the initial project I stayed on to help with making the in house framework unit an intigration testable, coach multiple junior programmers as well as interns, replaced JIRA with Team Foundation Server (TFS) to support the scrum process, added  Continues Integration (CI) & Continues Deployment (CD) with an OTAP street using Powershell. The CI/CD included back-copying and anonymising the production data to be able to refresh the development SqlServer databases. 
The preexisting micro-service architecture based on RabbitMQ was extended among other things with integration with the servicedesk tool ServiceNow, the customer  self service portal build in Asp.net MVC/knockout, the VMware virtual machine management, the Veeam back-up solutions and the Logstash (ELK stack) logging. I also created generic SQL scripts to set up data-warehouses and used R to do statics analysis.
profile_positions.title: Software Architect

profile_positions.description:
Tried to set up a FinTech start-up in the aircraft leasing sector.
Created the initial version of an innovative flexible scalable and reliable lease platform based on micro services, events sourcing and CQRS. It's architecture was intended to support an A1 "agile next" development process. With our solution companies could have more reliable and scalable IT, react faster on business opportunities and reduce development costs. 
Companies in low end nieces with innovative leasing concepts for e.g. jeans, led lighting and IT resources could optimize their "Time To Market" with our product. Similarly companies in high end nieces involving costly resources like aircraft's and ships with highly complex “tailor made” leases could also benefit by reducing their "Transaction costs".

Modern customers are only interested in use of assets and less in ownership. Ownership is seen as a burden instead of status, because of financing, insurance, maintenance, and finally reselling. Leasing takes care of all these areas for the customer, by banking, insuring, managing and mediating. All this makes leasing one of the most complex financial products there are. Small wonder financial institutions spend at least 1/6 of their operating cost on IT. We would like that leasing becomes possible for far more products and for far more customers by helping companies improve their IT.

Technically we are developed our solution around the Azure Service Fabric and Azure Event Hub, as those where the up and coming PaaS  technologies at the time. Previously our research had taken us from a regular solution made more reliable with NServiceBus/RabbidMQ an event sourcing solution running on Azure.

Ultimately I left the because without any income the development would take longer than my savings, but continued later with the SkyReckon venture.
profile_positions.title: Software Architect

profile_positions.description:
Omniplan creates financial planning software for independent professional financial planners (FFP) as well as those with ING and Rabobank. 
Financial planners give advice about financial products like montages, pensions, shares and every other financial product out there. Their knowledge scope is huge and the tool they use has to support that large scope, but also has to have enough depth of detail to be useful.
To make things even more interesting is that the field is rapidly changing under the legislative pressure of the AFM and the customer who now has to pay a fee for the advice.

The complex knowledge domain combined with it's rapid growth, creates difficulties and opportunities even for the most seasoned people. Although there is great pressure to deliver products on time, the company is  also trying to improving it's structure and way of work. 
I'm happy to be able to delivering products, who have an enormous impact on people, as buying a house for instance, is the biggest transaction most people do.
Although it's a balancing act, I'm also part of the improvement process. I improved the process by creating tools, documentation and giving instruction. I improved the technology by enhancing the architecture and design as well as hands on refactoring to conform code to the style guide, have unit test etc.

Ultimatly I left because I felt I was unable to improve things, although there was much to improve.
profile_positions.title: Software Architect

profile_positions.description:
I've laid the groundwork for further success in this sabbatical.
In the final months of the consultancy firm I worked for, prior to this, where though, and during the bankruptcy I had a bad experience with a headhunter. That summer, I filled up my mental reserves by going to the beach, solving some personal issues. I also helped a friend with 3d printers and laser cutters, as well as his ecological housing and gardening projects. 
After the summer while doing some websites, it hit me. First I just love defining architecture, analyzing requirements, coaching colleges and creating software. And second, it's important to me, to be successful at a meaningful job and having monetary value.
For a long time I felt that I couldn't reach the heights I wanted to, because of things holding me back. I realized that, if I started a job without changing anything, I would have the same results, Because the results of before, simply weren't enough, I changed a lot of things,

I become more credible by having a more business like look and style.
I improved my mental aptitude by studying zen and doing mental exercise.
I enhanced my physical condition by going for a run at 5  o'clock in the morning and going to the gym in the afternoon.
I improved my availability by finishing the mayor renovation of my house. 
In order to be of better service to a business I read up on economics and management theory.
I deepened my architecture knowledge by studying TOGAF, and SOA.
I solidified my development skills by going for .NET certifications, like ASP.NET and Entity Framework.
I improved my knowledge of the development process by studying agile methods like Scrum and TDD.
profile_positions.title: Student

profile_positions.description:
Integer was a consultancy firm that had been around for more than 30 years. For most of those years it was part of Ordina, but it went on its own again. Unfortunately going solo took a lot of effort and money and reinventing the company in the middle of the crisis was too much. The left overs where picket up by the Braincap group, witch they had cooperated with and where shareholders. 
I personally think they had a much better partner in Ordina, as those where trustworthy and whole lot less sly.
I think trust is the basis for any business and therefor would not take the deal Braincap offered me. I hold no grudge over what happened at Integer and Braincap. What they did was probably the smartest thing to do and largely dictated by circumstance. I wish all the people at Braincap all the best. So long and thanks for the fish.
profile_positions.title: Software Architect/Analyst/Developer/Consultant
